external.title: Syria appoints some foreign Islamist fighters to its military, sources say
external.description: Syria's new rulers have installed some foreign fighters including Uyghurs, a Jordanian and a Turk in the country's armed forces as Damascus tries to shape a patchwork of rebel groups into a professional military, two Syrian sources said.

Syria's de facto leader Ahmed al-Sharaa has tapped dozens of former rebels for high-ranking army positions, several of whom are foreign fighters, a war monitor and experts said on Monday.The new authorities in Damascus, from the ranks of Islamist-led rebels who until several weeks ago had fought to overthrow longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad, now face the daunting task of rebuilding state institutions.The Syrian army has effectively collapsed, much like other institutions set up by the Assad clan and their notorious security apparatuses.

He also said negotiations are underway with other factions across Syria, nothing that Syria could not become “a platform for the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) to launch attacks against Turkey.”

record.text:
Syria Leader: Elections Could Take Four Years

Syria’s de facto leader Ahmed al-Sharaa, also known as Abu Mohammed al-Golani, said Sunday that drafting a new constitution could take up to three years, while elections could take four.
